Smit*, K.H. Johnson Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA (Received September 27, 1993; accepted November 17, 1993) Abstract Transition metal sulphides are widely used as catalysts for the hydrodesulphurization (HDS) process of thiophene and related compounds. It is generally believed that, during adsorption of thiophene onto vacant sulphur sites on the surface of the catalyst, strong o, and it bonds are formed between the thiophene sulphur and catalyst metal atoms, with strong metal d and sulphur p character. From a series of scattered-wave electronic structure calculations on Ni-promoted MOS2-thiophene complexes for which the separation between the thiophene molecule and the catalyst is systematically varied, we show that metal-sulphur bonding is weak during adsorption. Strong interactions between the sulphur atom in thiophene and the sulphur atoms in the catalyst, operative at relatively large thiophene-catalyst separations, lead to weak binding of thiophene to the catalyst. A new mechanism for the adsorption of thiophene, not requiring sulphur vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, and based on sulphur-sulphur bonding, is proposed. It is shown that this adsorption mechanism can be an integral part of the overall HDS process if it occurs along the edges of (promoted) MOS2 catalysts. Keywords: density functionals; electronic structure calculations; hydrodesulphurization; sulphide catalysts; sulphur-sulphur bonding 1. Introduction Hydrodesulphurization (HDS) aided by transition metal sulphide catalysts is an important step in the processing of oil. The removal of sulphur is necessary to minimize the emission of sulphur dioxides (responsible for acid rain) which are formed when oil products *Corresponding author. 0304-5102/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSD10304-5102(94)00051-V 208 TS. Smit, K.H. Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 are burned. The HDS of thiophene, which is the prototype for an entire class of sulphurcontaining compounds, has therefore received much attention from experimentalists and theoreticians alike. Despite these efforts, Prins et al. recently concluded that the key question of how an HDS catalyst functions is completely open again [ 1 ] . It is nonetheless believed that, in the initial stages of the HDS process, thiophene binds to the catalyst through its sulphur atom, on vacant sulphur sites on the surface of the catalyst. This is the so-called one-point end-on mechanism. On the basis of a series of scattered-wave density-functional calculations on simple catalyst-thiophene complexes, we recently showed that par interactions between the sulphur atom in the thiophene molecule (which will henceforth be referred to as ST) and the sulphur atoms in the catalyst are responsible for weak thiophene-catalyst binding during the adsorption of thiophene onto the catalyst, rather than the establishment of metal d-ST p bonds, as was widely believed [ 2 ] . The absence of metal-sulphur bonding during adsorption suggests that exposed metal atoms may not be necessary for the adsorption of thiophene onto the catalyst. Salmeron et al. observed that thiophene can adsorb onto the basal plane of MOS2, consisting entirely of sulphur atoms [ 3 ] . The heat of adsorption is small for basal plane adsorption, indicating that only weak substrate-adsorbate bonds are formed. Subsequent desulphurization does not occur, for it is well-known that only the edges of MOS2 sheets, where metal atoms are exposed, are catalytically active [ 3-5 ] . It is likely that strong substrate-ST bonds are necessary for desulphurization, probably metalsulphur bonds. Since these bonds are not formed even if thiophene adsorbs into a sulphur vacancy, alternative adsorption mechanisms, which do not require sulphur surface vacancies, may be operative. As long as such a mechanism allows for the subsequent formation of metal-sulphur bonds, it can be part of the overall HDS reaction. The object of this paper is to investigate the possibility of adsorption of thiophene along the edges of MOSz sheets through a mechanism based on sulphur-sulphur interactions alone. Specifically, we report the results of scattered-wave calculations of the adsorption process of thiophene on promoted transition metal sulphide catalysts. When promoter elements such as Ni or Co are added to the binary molybdenum-sulphide, the catalytic activity increases significantly [ 6] . Some claim that this is purely a promotion effect, while others argue that the promoter atoms are themselves the catalysts (for a good review of the various models, see [ 1 ] ) . One of the main challenges in HDS research therefore is to accurately characterize the local structure of the catalyst, in order to identify the catalytically active sites. Based on EXAFS measurements, Bouwens et al. report a possible structure for Ni-promoted MOS2, with Ni in the plane of the Mo atoms (Fig. 1) [ 7 ] . Electronic structure calculations have been carried out on the geometry suggested by Bouwens et al. Combined with an analysis of the electronic structure of thiophene, we suggest the possibility of a new reaction mechanism for the HDS process, not requiring sulphur vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, but based on sulphur-sulphur bonding. This new adsorption mechanism, which will be referred to as the sulphur-sulphur mechanism, has been studied by performing a series of calculations on catalyst-thiophene complexes. By varying the distance between the thiophene molecule and the catalyst, the important orbital interactions can be identified and studied. Our results indicate that strong interactions between ST and the catalyst sulphur atom located in the Mo-Ni plane (SE in Fig. 1) occur, resulting in weak-to-moderate bonding (as indicated by the heat of adsorption). Further calculations on catalysts with a surface sulphur vacancy show that the heat T.S. Smit, K.H. Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 209 sulphur nickel Ss molybdenum Fig. 1. Strong sulphursulphur interactions are again observed. Metal-sulphur bonding, although more important than for the model adsorption complexes reported previously [ 2 ] , does not dominate the adsorption process. The implications of these results for the entire HDS process will be discussed. 2. Computational method The results presented in this paper have all been obtained using the scattered-wave density-functional formalism of Johnson and Smith [ 8 ] , modified for overlapping spheres. In this method, the space of a polyatomic cluster is divided into three regions, (1) atomic: overlapping spheres centred on the constituent atoms, (2) interatomic: the region between the atomic spheres and an outer sphere surrounding the entire cluster, and (3) extramolecular: the region outside the outer sphere. The potential is spherically averaged in regions (1) and (3), spatially averaged in region (2). In the multiple-scattering formalism, the atoms of the cluster are treated as scatterers of "electronic" waves. By matching the expansion of the wave functions in the various regions on the boundaries between them, a rapidly convergent secular determinant is obtained. The solution is used to construct a new 210 TS. Smit, KH. Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 potential; the entire process is then repeated until self-consistency is obtained. The exchangecorrelation potential of Hedin and Lundqvist was employed [9] . A Watson sphere was used to mimic the stabilizing Madelung potential of a crystalline environment [ 10] . In the process of iterating towards self-consistency, large fluctuations may occur in the energy levels of the orbitals. As a result it may be necessary to repopulate the orbitals between subsequent iterations, thereby introducing significant changes in the potential. In this procedure, repeated switching of the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied orbital (HOMO and LUMO) is sometimes encountered. To avoid this problem, fractional occupation numbers for the orbitals have in some cases been used. In previous calculations we found that by using a Fermi-Dirac distribution for the occupation of the orbitals, the speed of convergence can be greatly improved. Thiophene Thiophene, CQHQS, is a planar molecule with point group symmetry CZ . Its electronic structure is in many ways very similar to that of, e.g., benzene. The two highest occupied molecular orbitals lie well below the LUMO (the energy gap is approximately 4 eV), yet well above the next occupied orbital (by about 3 eV). Both orbitals are combinations of p contributions from the various ring atoms, perpendicular to the plane of the molecule. The HOMO has a2 character and no contribution from the sulphur atom. The other of the two orbitals has b, character and has a very large sulphur content (38%). This orbital is antibonding between the sulphur atom and the carbon atoms in the ring (Fig. 2) and is often referred to as a sulphur "lone pair". In this paper we are investigating only the first part of the HDS process, i.e., the adsorption of the thiophene molecule on the surface of the catalyst. It should however be noted that the character of this orbital makes it a good candidate for playing a major role in the breaking of the sulphur-carbon bonds, a necessary step in the second part of the HDS process, i.e., the formation of butadiene. In calculations on octahedral MSS - clusters (where M designates a transition metal atom and n is the total charge of the cluster; one sulphur atom was substituted by a vacancy) as simple models for binary transition metal sulphide catalysts, we showed that the b, orbital participates in strong par interactions between the ST atom and the sulphur atoms in the catalyst. The az orbital is involved in pa carbon-sulphur interactions [2]. We expect a similarly important role for these orbitals for the case of promoted transition metal sulphide catalysts. 4. Ni-promoted MOS2 catalysts 4.1. (Electronic) structure In binary MOS2 the Mo atom is located at the center of a trigonal bipyramid. The bulk structure is composed of layers of Mo sandwiched between layers of sulphur. The MOS2 sheets are stacked on top of each other, with weak Van der Waals bonding between the sheets. In the structure reported by Bouwens et al. [7] for Ni-promoted MOS2 (Fig. 1), the Ni atoms lie in the plane of the Mo atoms, decorating the edges of MOS2 sheets (see also Louwers and Prins [ 11 ] . Startsev [ 12 ] has shown that the edge structure of Co-promoted MOS2, the catalyst most frequently used in industry, is very similar. EXAFS measurements by Bouwens and co-workers confirm this [ 13,14]. One of the most interesting features of the geometry of Fig. 1 is the fivefold coordination of the Ni atom: one of the sulphur atoms (SE) lies in the Mo-Ni plane, forming a square pyramid around the Ni atom in combination with two sulphur atoms above and two below this plane (SB). However, the experimental uncertainty in the Ni coordination number is high (5.3 1.0). As a result, the possibility of 4- or 6-fold coordination cannot be excluded. For example, six-fold coordination of the promoter element has been observed for carbon-supported Co-Mo-S [ 13] (but five-fold coordination when Si02 or A1203 is used as a support [ 15 ] ) . Similarly, Louwers et al. report a six-fold coordination for Ni in Ni-W-S supported on carbon [ 16] . Scattered-wave calculations were carried out for the Ni-promoted MOSz structure shown 212 T.S. Smit, K.H Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 in Fig. 1, point group symmetry CZ . A Watson sphere was used in the calculations; all atoms were given the charge according to their formal oxidation state ( -2, +4 and +2 for S, Mo and Ni respectively; in the calculations reported in this paper, the possible reduction of Mo by Ni [ 12,6] has not been taken into account). Two orbitals close to the Fermi level (irreducible representations b, and b2) show a very large SE-p content: 42(40) % SE-p VS, 16(15) % Ni-d and 10(11) % S,-p. Much lower in energy lies an a, orbital which is almost exclusively SE-s in character (87%). 4.2. Implications for the adsorption of thiophene It is assumed that the thiophene molecule adsorbs upright on the surface of the catalyst, i.e., that the end-on one-point mechanism is operative. In this mechanism, adsorption of the thiophene molecule to the catalyst is supposed to occur on sulphur vacancies, where the ST atom binds to an exposed metal atom. In a recent paper [2] we have shown that metalsulphur interactions are weak and operative at relatively small thiophene-catalyst separations, leading to weak metal-sulphur bonds. Sulphur-sulphur interactions are strong and operative at relatively large thiophene-catalyst separations, leading to weak binding of the thiophene molecule to the catalyst. Hence the electronic structure of the Ni-promoted MoSZ catalyst shown in Fig. 1, particularly the presence of the SE-p dominated orbitals close to the Fermi level, in combination with the ST-p dominated thiophene bl orbital (Fig. 2), suggests the possibility of the formation of ST-SE p7r bonds if thiophene adsorbs directly onto the SE atom. On this basis we hypothesize that the thiophene molecule can bind to the sulphur atom located in the Mo-Ni plane through par sulphur-sulphur interactions (we will later see that ST-SE o' bonds are also formed). In this adsorption mechanism, sulphursulphur interactions must be responsible for binding the thiophene molecule to the catalyst, since the metal atom is shielded by the apical sulphur atom (SE): a sulphur vacancy need not be present on the surface of the catalyst for the adsorption of thiophene. Once a thiophene-catalyst adsorption complex has been formed, subsequent desulphurization must involve cleavage of the C-ST bonds. Hydrogenation of the thiophene molecule significantly weakens these bonds and probably precedes desulphurization [ 17,18 ] . Regardless of the details of the hydrogenation and desulphurization mechanism, it is clear that the ST atom of thiophene can form an SZ unit with the apical sulphur atom (SE) on the edge of the catalyst during these stages of the HDS process. This may lead to a sixfold coordination of the Ni atom. For example, the ST SE unit may lie in the Mo-Ni plane, in which case there will be an electrostatic attraction between Ni and the electron cloud between the two sulphur atoms on the edge, in addition to direct orbital interactions. This is consistent with experimental findings [ 13,14] and supported by full-potential density-functional calculations [ 19] . This SZ unit will most likely be unstable in the HZ/HZS environment in which the HDS process takes place. Attack by hydrogen will result in the formation of HZS and either regenerate the original edge structure (with a five-fold coordinated Ni atom), or lead to an exposed Ni atom (four-fold coordination), as shown in Fig. 3A. In the sulphur-sulphur mechanism we propose, a sulphur vacancy is not required for the adsorption of thiophene onto the catalyst. The proposed reaction mechanism is not inconsistent with the presence of elemental sulphur and other sulphur species on the surface of the transition metal sulphide TS. Smit, KH. In this model, the vacancies are supposed to have been created through the prior combination of hydrogen with sulphur forming HZS (the HDS process takes place in an HZ/HZS environment). We do not dispute the validity of this process (although to our knowledge no accurate electronic structure calculations of this vacancy creation mechanism have yet been reported), but merely hypothesize that the process shown in Fig. 3A, may be operative simultaneously. This mechanism has not previously been reported, perhaps because of the emphasis on metal d-sulphur p interactions, rather than sulphur-sulphur p-rr interactions. These are of course not the only orbital interactions which occur when the thiophene molecule is lowered onto the catalyst. We highlight these particular orbitals, because significant changes in orbital character take place when the thiophene molecule is still relatively far removed from the catalyst surface. The results clearly show that ST-SE bonding can indeed occur, as we hypothesized on the basis of specific orbital topologies for the thiophene molecule and the catalyst separately. This is also evident from the heat of adsorption (the energy difference between the adsorption complex and the separate thiophene molecule and catalyst cluster), approximately 1.7 eV. The substrate-adsorbate interaction is attractive, but rather weak. It must be emphasized that these calculations only concern the first step of the HDS process, i.e., the adsorption of thiophene on the surface of the catalyst. We believe that the results presented here provide sufficient evidence for the acceptance of the sulphursulphur adsorption mechanism given in Fig. 3A. 5.2. We wish to determine whether the adsorption process is governed by the formation of Ni-d-ST-p bonds or alternatively by par interactions between the SB atoms in the catalyst and the ST and neighbouring carbon atoms in the thiophene molecule. The Ni-ST separation has been decreased from 5.676 a.u. down to 4.176 a.u. in steps of 0.5 a.u.. The most profound changes in orbital character at large Ni-ST separations occur for two clearly identifiable pairs of orbitals. In each case, one of the orbitals of the pair is one of the two highest occupied orbitals of the thiophene molecule (described in section 2), the other one is a catalyst orbital. Figs. 8 and 9 show the changing character of one of these pairs as thiophene adsorbs onto the catalyst. The p-rr S,-S, (-Ni) bonding and antibonding orbitals result from the interaction between the thiophene orbital shown in Fig. 2, and a catalyst b, orbital with significant py contributions on SB as well as dy, contributions from the Ni atom. Exactly the same type of interaction was identified for highly simplified model catalyst clusters (for a more elaborate description of this interaction on the basis of orbital topologies see [2] and the next section of this paper). C-SB p7r interactions involving the thiophene HOMO (not shown) have also been previously observed for the simplified catalyst structures. Metal-sulphur interactions are weak (although they appear to be stronger than for these simplified structures [ 2 ] . The heat of adsorption (1.5 eV) is of similar magnitude as for the sulphur-sulphur mechanism, indicating the absence of strong bonds between the exposed metal atom and the thiophene ST atom. No attempt was made to distinguish between metal-sulphur and sulphur-sulphur contributions, although it was concluded that in bulk MoS2, the sulphur-sulphur interactions are non-bonding or weakly bonding. Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 219 strong metal-sulphur bonding. Calculations on dihydrothiophene-TMS clusters reveal that strong metal-sulphur bonds are formed during the hydrogenation of thiophene following adsorption. The difference in bond strength between different TMS forms the basis for understanding activity differences between various TMS, as discussed in separate papers [ 17,23 ] . The calculations reported here show that these bonds do not form during adsorption of thiophene. Even in the case of sulphur vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, where the Ni atom is exposed, p7r S,-S, interactions are responsible for binding the ring molecule to the catalyst, rather than metal d-sulphur p interactions. 6. Discussion In this section some of the limitations associated with (i) the scattered-wave formalism, and (ii) the choice of geometry, will be discussed. A brief discussion of our main findings will also be given. Despite its successful application to many problems in chemistry and materials science, the scattered-wave model, and in particular its use of muffin-tin averaged potentials, has received much attention/ criticism over the years. The inability to calculate accurate total energy figures with this method is well known. Consequently, the values reported for the heat of adsorption are only approximate, but nonetheless consistent with earlier reports [ 8,21,22 ] . Our conclusions are based not on total energy differences but instead on specific orbital interactions. For example, the topologies of specific orbitals led us to propose a particular reaction mechanism. We believe that the scattered-wave method is very well suited for this approach. Nonetheless, for thiophene-catalyst separations larger than the ones for which results are reported in this paper, difficulties in doing the calculations have been encountered. The likely cause is the inaccurate representation of the potential in the (large) interstitial region. These problems can be circumvented by partitioning the thiophene-catalyst complex into subclusters, each of which has its own interstitial region and potential [ 24 ] . Alternatively, a full-potential quantum chemistry method may be used [ 19 ] . Secondly, the geometry of the adsorption models for which calculations have been performed, warrants further discussion. From the start, our investigations have been limited to an end-on reaction model, i.e., the axis of symmetry of the thiophene molecule coincides with the symmetry-axis of the catalyst cluster. By having the thiophene molecule lie in the Mo-Ni plane, the model has the same point group symmetry as the components from which it has been built, i.e., Cz . This greatly influences the speed of the calculations: any rotation of the thiophene molecule about the z-axis other than by 90 , would destroy all symmetry, hence destroy the block-diagonal form of the secular determinant. However, specific orbital topologies form the basis for the novel reaction mechanism proposed in this paper, so one may question the effect of rotating the thiophene molecule. Its effects on the standard endon mechanism must also be investigated. First consider the sulphur-sulphur mechanism. The so- interaction, shown in Figs. 6 and 7, is independent of the rotation angle, but the per interaction of Figs. 4 and 5 is not. There are two catalyst orbitals close to the Fermi level with strong SE-pX/py character respectively. When thiophene lies in the xz- or yz-plane, the thiophene orbital of Fig. 2 can interact with only one of these orbitals (one or the other). Any other choice would imply that this 220 TS. Smit, K H. Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 thiophene orbital interacts with both these orbitals, the strength of the interaction with each of them depending on the rotation angle. The interaction mechanism would remain unchanged, and is independent of our choice of geometry. We conclude that the basic chemistry does not change when the thiophene molecule is rotated about the z-axis. Next, consider the standard end-on mechanism, based on a sulphur vacancy on the surface of the catalyst. In the previous section, two pairs of interacting orbitals were identified, one involving sulphur-sulphur (ST-S13) interactions, the other involving carbon-sulphur (CSB) interactions. Symmetry arguments indicate why the sulphur-sulphur interactions are dominant in the adsorption process. Carbon-sulphur interactions are strongly dependent on the geometry of the adsorption complex. If the thiophene molecule does not lie in the MoNi plane but is rotated by 45 (so that the plane of the molecule is now spanned by one of the diagonals of the SB square and the z-axis) carbon-sulphur interactions are forbidden by symmetry. The strength of the carbon-sulphur interaction is a function of the rotation angle 0 of the thiophene molecule about the z-axis, and vanishes completely for 0=45 . This is not the case for the sulphur-sulphur interactions. The thiophene b, orbital of Figs. 2 and 8 interacts with a catalyst b, orbital with strong SB p,, contributions. Close to this orbital lie several b2 orbitals with significant SB px contributions. These orbitals are candidates for interactions if the thiophene molecule is rotated by 90 . A rotation by 0 < 0 < 90 would imply that the thiophene orbital in Fig. 2 would interact with a combination of b, and b2 orbitals. The interaction strength with each of them depends on the exact value of the rotation angle 0. Based on calculations on model clusters reported previously [ 2 ] , we do not expect the strength of the total interaction to be highly dependent on the rotation angle. In other words, rotation of the thiophene molecule about the z-axis affects only the carbonsulphur interactions, not the sulphur-sulphur interactions and we conclude that the latter interaction is dominant in the adsorption process. We conclude that the specific geometry of the adsorption complex does not limit the validity of our findings. We conclude that adsorption of thiophene on TMS catalysts is possible through a mechanism based solely on sulphur-sulphur bonding. If adsorption occurs on the edges of promoted MoS2 catalysts, a slight reconstruction of the edge results in the possibility of the formation of additional metal-sulphur bonds. These bonds appear to be necessary for the latter stages of the HDS process. Hence, sulphur-sulphur adsorption can be an integral part of the HDS process, if it occurs along the edges of MOS2. In contrast, basal plane adsorption, albeit possible, does not allow for the formation of metal-sulphur bonds in the subsequent stages of the HDS process, since all the metal atoms are shielded by sulphur. As a result, the basal planes of MOS2 are catalytically inactive. In summary, metal-sulphur bonds are necessary for desulphurization, but not for the adsorption of thiophene. This is evident also from the adsorption of thiophene into an anion surface vacancy. Even then sulphur-sulphur interactions dominate. The probable explanation is the strong involvement of ST in the 77-electron system of thiophene. This is evident from the fact that ST carries a small positive charge (or at best neutral) in free thiophene. In a separate paper we show that hydrogenation of thiophene weakens the C-ST bonds, and, through the formation of metal-ST bonds, facilitates desulphurization [ 17 ] . Obviously, in dihydrothiophene and tetrahydrothiophene, the ST atom is much less involved in the ir electron system. The remarkable agreement between the calculations on the highly simplified model TS. Smit, KH. Johnson /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 91 (1994) 207-222 221 catalyst structures [ 2] and the experimentally determined Ni-Mo-S structure indicates that by not allowing relaxation of the internal thiophene and catalyst coordinates, the conclusions are not affected in a major way (although the exact geometry of the intermediate reaction products remains an open question). The results presented furthermore show that the investigation of orbital topologies is a very powerful method for studying chemical reactions. 7. Conclusions This study shows that adsorption of thiophene onto a TMS catalyst does not require sulphur vacancies on the surface of the catalyst but can occur through a mechanism based exclusively on sulphur-sulphur bonding. If sulphur-sulphur adsorption occurs along the edges of (promoted) MOS2 catalysts, this mechanism can be an integral part of the overall HDS process and may lead to the formation of anion surface vacancies. Even if metal atoms are exposed and the standard end-on mechanism is operative, sulphur-sulphur interactions, operative at relatively large separations between the thiophene molecule and the catalyst, dominate the adsorption process and lead to weak binding. Weak metal-sulphur interactions are operative at small separations and lead to weak metal-sulphur bonds. Acknowledgements One of us (T.S.S.) wishes to thank S. Eijsbouts, J.N. Louwen, E.T.C. It is generally believed that, during adsorption of thiophene onto vacant sulphur sites on the surface of the catalyst, strong σ and π bonds are formed between the thiophene sulphur and catalyst metal atoms, with strong metal d and sulphur p character.
